title: 107_s376
content: Three-year modification of procedures relating to assistance for countries not cooperating with United States counterdrug efforts. Amendment to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to limit assistance during fiscal years 2002, 2003, and 2004 for countries not cooperating with US counterdrug efforts. The President must report to Congress by November 1 of 2001, 2002, and 2003, identifying countries not cooperating with US drug control goals for potential sanctions. The President must report to Congress by March 1 of 2002, 2003, and 2004, identifying countries subject to sanctions for non-compliance with US drug control goals as per bilateral agreements. The President must consider various factors when determining whether a country should be identified in a report for non-compliance with drug control goals, including meeting UN objectives and bilateral agreements with the US. The President must consider factors like preventing public corruption and maintaining opium production levels when determining a country's compliance with drug control goals. The President may omit a country from a report on illicit opium cultivation for national security reasons, with a requirement to explain the risks involved if the country is not omitted. The President can exclude a country from a report on illicit opium cultivation for national security reasons, with a need to justify the risks involved if the country is not excluded. Congressional action is required through a joint resolution by March 30 of the fiscal year for the provisions to apply to a country. The joint resolution can only apply to a country if it was not identified in the report for that fiscal year. In the fiscal year, a country not identified in the report under subsection (b) will face withholding of bilateral assistance starting on March 1. Senate procedures for joint resolutions will follow the International Security Assistance and Arms Export Control Act of 1976. In the case of a country identified in a report under subsection (b), fifty percent of US assistance will be withheld from obligation and expenditure. For multilateral assistance, the Secretary of the Treasury will instruct the US Executive Director of each multilateral development bank to vote against any loan or fund utilization for the country. In this subsection, the term 'multilateral development bank' includes the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the International Development Association, the Inter-American Development Bank, the Asian Development Bank, the African Development Bank, and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The term 'appropriate committees of Congress' refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to limit applicability during fiscal years 2002, 2003, and 2004. Assistance limitations for countries not cooperating with US counterdrug efforts are outlined in section 490A. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to section 489(a)(3)(A) for the specified fiscal years. Inclusion of major drug trafficking organizations in international narcotics control strategy report is emphasized in section 2. Section 489 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include the identification of major drug trafficking organizations and their activities in the preceding fiscal years. The term "major drug trafficking organization" is defined as any group involved in significant illicit drug-related activities. The amended section prohibits engaging in illegal drug activities, money laundering, or assisting others in such activities. It defines terms like narcotic drug, controlled substance, and listed chemical according to the Controlled Substances Act.
